result.markdown:
--- author: Thadryan title: "Stats Python in a Hurry Part 2: Visualization" date: 2022-12-12 description: Transferring my R data viz knowledge back to my first language. bibliography: Part2.bib toc: true --- # Data Visualization ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import numpy as np import statsmodels.api as sm import seaborn as sns import matplotlib.pyplot as plt ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} df = sm.datasets.get_rdataset("mtcars", "datasets", cache = True).data df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 4 4
Datsun 710 22.8 4 108.0 93 3.85 2.320 18.61 1 1 4 1
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258.0 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 3 1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360.0 175 3.15 3.440 17.02 0 0 3 2
``` ::: ::: Seaborn seems to be the most efficient way to get decent looking exploratory plots in a hurry. ## Line Plot ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.lineplot(df, x = "mpg", y = "disp") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-4-output-2.png){width=600 height=429} ::: ::: ### Line Plot by factor Use the `hue` argument to break out factors into separate lines. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.lineplot(df, x = "mpg", y = "disp", hue = "am") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-5-output-2.png){width=600 height=429} ::: ::: ### Line plot with linear trend Mean/CI are automatic if you melt the df. ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_long = pd.melt(df, id_vars = "cyl", value_vars = "mpg") df_long ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}
cyl variable value
0 6 mpg 21.0
1 6 mpg 21.0
2 4 mpg 22.8
3 6 mpg 21.4
4 8 mpg 18.7
5 6 mpg 18.1
6 8 mpg 14.3
7 4 mpg 24.4
8 4 mpg 22.8
9 6 mpg 19.2
10 6 mpg 17.8
11 8 mpg 16.4
12 8 mpg 17.3
13 8 mpg 15.2
14 8 mpg 10.4
15 8 mpg 10.4
16 8 mpg 14.7
17 4 mpg 32.4
18 4 mpg 30.4
19 4 mpg 33.9
20 4 mpg 21.5
21 8 mpg 15.5
22 8 mpg 15.2
23 8 mpg 13.3
24 8 mpg 19.2
25 4 mpg 27.3
26 4 mpg 26.0
27 4 mpg 30.4
28 8 mpg 15.8
29 6 mpg 19.7
30 8 mpg 15.0
31 4 mpg 21.4
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.lineplot(df_long, x = "cyl", y = "value") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-7-output-2.png){width=585 height=429} ::: ::: Or, use `lmplot` to git a linear model like you'd get with `geom_smooth(method = lm)`. ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.lmplot(df, x = "mpg", y = "disp") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-8-output-2.png){width=470 height=470} ::: ::: ## Box Plot ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.boxplot(df, x = "cyl", y = "mpg") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-9-output-2.png){width=585 height=433} ::: ::: ## Histogram ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.histplot(df, x = "wt") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-10-output-2.png){width=585 height=429} ::: ::: ## Density Plot ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.kdeplot(df, x = "disp") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-11-output-2.png){width=614 height=429} ::: ::: ## Heatmap ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.heatmap(df[["disp", "hp"]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-12-output-2.png){width=650 height=412} ::: ::: ## Multiple Variable Plots ### KDE ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.kdeplot(df.loc[:, ["mpg", "wt"]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-13-output-2.png){width=606 height=411} ::: ::: ### Lineplot ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.lineplot(df.loc[:, ["mpg", "wt"]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-14-output-2.png){width=580 height=411} ::: ::: ## Faceting ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} # create three empty spots grid = sns.FacetGrid(data = df, col = "cyl", col_wrap=2) # puts a historgram on each of them grid.map(sns.histplot, "wt") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-15-output-2.png){width=566 height=566} ::: ::: The initial display is automatic. If you want to show the same plot again, access the `figure` property of the object. ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} # just typing it out gives the object metadata grid ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} grid.figure ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-17-output-1.png){width=566 height=566} ::: ::: ## Tweaking Plots ### Axis Labels The plot we made of weight and mpg had mostly unusable x tick labels. Let's revist it. ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} p_line = sns.lineplot(df.loc[:, ["mpg", "wt"]]) p_line.figure ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-18-output-1.png){width=580 height=411} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-18-output-2.png){width=580 height=411} ::: ::: The syntax is a little awkward. Essentially there is a set method, and you use a get method to retrieve the labels to pass into it, specifying a rotation. ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} # set what you get from the get method v--here p_line.set_xticklabels(p_line.get_xticklabels(), rotation = 45) p_line.figure ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /tmp/ipykernel_9407/667538073.py:2: UserWarning: FixedFormatter should only be used together with FixedLocator p_line.set_xticklabels(p_line.get_xticklabels(), rotation = 45) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-19-output-2.png){width=573 height=498} ::: ::: They still conflict a little. We can make them a little smaller overall. The technique is the same, just setting a different property. ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} p_line.set_xticklabels(p_line.get_xticklabels(), size = 5) p_line.figure ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /tmp/ipykernel_9407/3729791072.py:1: UserWarning: FixedFormatter should only be used together with FixedLocator p_line.set_xticklabels(p_line.get_xticklabels(), size = 5) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-20-output-2.png){width=566 height=449} ::: ::: ### Title ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} p_line.set(title = "0_o") p_line.figure ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-21-output-1.png){width=566 height=468} ::: ::: ### Color Schemes #### Discrete Seaborn lets you preview color palettes by calling them as a function argument to `sns.color_palette`. ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.color_palette("dark") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: The plotting functions will then have arguments for color scheming: ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} p_box = sns.boxplot(df, x = "cyl", y = "mpg", palette = "dark") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-23-output-1.png){width=585 height=433} ::: ::: #### Continuous ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.color_palette("mako", as_cmap = True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ```{=html}
mako
under
bad
over
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.heatmap(df[["disp", "hp"]], cmap = "mako") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-25-output-2.png){width=650 height=412} ::: :::
